**Things feeling easier, less exhausting:**
You're noticing things are just easier now—not easy, but less exhausting. You can notice good things when they happen instead of immediately finding the threat. That's exactly the shift we've been tracking: your baseline has come up, the catastrophizing is quieter, and you have more capacity to be with what's actually happening instead of what your brain predicts might go wrong. This is what recovery looks like. Not dramatic, not a lightning bolt—just things getting gradually more livable.

**Feeling guilty about feeling better:**
And now you feel almost guilty about feeling better, like you don't deserve to feel this ok. Yeah, that's another pattern. When you've spent months or years in survival mode, feeling good can feel wrong—like you're forgetting to brace for something, or like you're not allowed to rest because the other shoe is going to drop. Your nervous system got so used to high alert that calm feels suspicious.

But here's the thing: you do deserve to feel ok. You've done the work. You've practiced noticing catastrophizing, testing it against reality, acting even when you're anxious, redirecting when the spiral starts. You've built skills, gathered evidence, shifted your baseline. Feeling better isn't something you have to earn or justify—it's just what happens when you stop spending all your energy on imaginary threats. You're allowed to let it be good. The guilt is just your brain's last-ditch effort to find something wrong when things are actually going well. Notice it, let it be there, and keep living your life anyway. You've got this.
